If the victim has collapsed, had a seizure, has trouble breathing, or can't be awakened, immediately call emergency services at 911. Symptoms of overdose may include: fever change in ability to taste food sudden tightening of the muscles numbness or tingling around the mouth What other information should I know? Keep all appointments with your doctor and the laboratory. Your doctor will order certain lab tests to check your body's response to pamidronate injection. Keep a written list of all of the prescription and nonprescription (over-the-counter) medicines, vitamins, minerals, and dietary supplements you are taking. Bring this list with you each time you visit a doctor or if you are admitted to the hospital. You should carry the list with you in case of emergencies. Brand names Aredia Â® Other names ADP Sodium AHPrBP Sodium

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Phenylephrine is used to relieve nasal and sinus congestion caused by colds, allergies, or sinusitis. A prescription injectable form may be used in medical settings to raise low blood pressure. How should this medicine be used? For over the counter oral use, follow the product label or your prescribers directions. Typical adult dosing is 10 milligrams by mouth every 4 hours as needed with a maximum of 60 milligrams in 24 hours. Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest time. Do not use for more than 7 days unless directed. For children use only products labeled for their age and follow dosing carefully. How should this medicine be used if it is a nasal spray or drops? Use exactly as directed, usually 1 to 2 sprays or drops in each nostril every 4 hours as needed for up to 3 days to avoid rebound congestion. Do not share the bottle and avoid contaminating the tip. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you are taking or have taken a monoamine oxidase inhibitor within the last 14 days. Tell your doctor if you have high blood pressure, heart disease, diabetes, thyroid disease, glaucoma, an enlarged prostate, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. Avoid taking other cold or allergy products that also contain decongestants or stimulants. Phenylephrine may cause nervousness or trouble sleeping so avoid taking it near bedtime. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Limit caffeine and other stimulants which can increase side effects such as jitteriness and rapid heartbeat. Drink plenty of fluids if you are congested. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is usually taken as needed. If you are on a schedule, take it when you remember, but skip it if it is almost time for your next dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include nervousness, dizziness, headache, increased blood pressure, palpitations, and trouble sleeping. Stop use and seek medical help for chest pain, severe or persistent headache, rapid or irregular heartbeat, severe high blood pressure symptoms, or signs of an allergic reaction such as rash, swelling, or trouble breathing.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Pyrethrin with piperonyl butoxide is used to treat head lice and their eggs and may also be used for pubic lice when directed. It kills live lice but not all eggs, so retreatment is often needed. How should this medicine be used? For head lice apply to dry hair and scalp enough to thoroughly wet the hair. Leave on for 10 minutes, then add a small amount of water, lather, and rinse thoroughly. Use a fine tooth nit comb to remove lice and nits while the hair is still damp. Repeat in 7 to 10 days to kill newly hatched lice unless your clinician advises otherwise. Treat close contacts as recommended and wash or heat dry clothing, hats, bedding, and combs used within the prior 48 hours. Avoid contact with eyes, nose, and mouth. Do not use on eyelashes or eyebrows. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you are allergic to pyrethrins, chrysanthemums, or ragweed. Use with caution if you have asthma or very sensitive skin. For external use only. Do not use on broken or inflamed skin. Keep away from open flame because the product may be flammable. Ask a clinician before use in children under 2 years, during pregnancy, or while breastfeeding. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special dietary instructions are needed. What should I do if I forget a dose? Apply as soon as you remember if lice are still present, then continue with the planned retreatment schedule. Do not apply more often than directed. What side effects can this medication cause? Mild itching, redness, tingling, or burning of the scalp are common and usually temporary. Stop use and seek medical help if you develop swelling, hives, trouble breathing, or severe irritation.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Antipyrine and benzocaine ear drops are used to relieve ear pain and pressure and to help soften earwax, often alongside other treatments for ear conditions. How should this medicine be used? Warm the bottle in your hands. Lie with the affected ear upward. Instill enough drops to fill the ear canal as directed. Insert a clean cotton plug if advised and moisten it with a few drops. For pain you may repeat every 1 to 2 hours as needed or as directed. For earwax softening use drops up to 3 times daily for 2 to 3 days before earwax removal as instructed by your clinician. Do not use if you have a perforated eardrum or ear tubes unless directed by a clinician. Do not touch the dropper tip to the ear or any surface. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you are allergic to benzocaine, other local anesthetics, or antipyrine. Seek medical evaluation for severe pain, fever, drainage, trauma, or hearing loss. For ear use only. Keep out of reach of children. Use with caution in infants and young children because benzocaine can rarely cause methemoglobinemia. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special dietary instructions are needed. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is often used as needed. If on a schedule, use it when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. Do not double doses. What side effects can this medication cause? Mild local irritation, redness, or itching can occur. Stop use and seek immediate medical help if you notice gray or blue colored skin, shortness of breath, extreme fatigue, fast heart rate, or confusion which may indicate methemoglobinemia, or if you have signs of a severe allergic reaction.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Hydrocortisone injection is a corticosteroid used to treat adrenal insufficiency, severe allergic reactions, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbations, certain autoimmune and inflammatory conditions, and some forms of shock. How should this medicine be used? It is usually given by a healthcare professional into a vein or muscle. Dose and duration are individualized. If you have adrenal insufficiency, your clinician may provide an emergency injection kit and instructions for use during illness or injury and will advise you to wear medical identification. Do not stop long term corticosteroids suddenly without medical guidance because of the risk of adrenal crisis. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about infections, recent exposure to chickenpox or measles, diabetes, high blood pressure, glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, stomach ulcers, mood disorders, seizure disorder, liver disease, or pregnancy or breastfeeding. Hydrocortisone can increase infection risk and may mask signs of infection. Avoid live vaccines while on significant immunosuppressive doses. Many medicines can interact, including certain antifungals, antibiotics, seizure medicines, and HIV medicines. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Your clinician may advise limiting sodium, ensuring enough calcium and vitamin D, and managing carbohydrates if you have diabetes or steroid induced hyperglycemia. Maintain adequate hydration. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you are on a scheduled regimen, take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose, then skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you have adrenal insufficiency and symptoms of adrenal crisis occur, use your emergency injection as instructed and seek emergency care. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include fluid retention, swelling, increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, anxiety or insomnia, elevated blood pressure, elevated blood sugar, stomach upset, acne, and increased sweating. Serious effects include signs of infection, vision changes or eye pain, severe mood or behavior changes, stomach bleeding, pancreatitis, severe muscle or bone pain, hip or shoulder pain suggestive of avascular necrosis, and adrenal suppression. Injection site pain or infection can occur.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Serious neurologic adverse reactions including spinal cord infarction, paraplegia, quadriplegia, cortical blindness, and stroke have occurred with epidural administration of corticosteroids. Methylprednisolone injection should not be given by epidural or intrathecal routes. Corticosteroids can suppress the immune system, increase the risk of serious infections, and mask signs of infection. Do not stop long term therapy suddenly because of the risk of adrenal crisis. Why is this medication prescribed? Methylprednisolone injection is a corticosteroid used to treat severe allergic reactions, asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease exacerbations, autoimmune and inflammatory disorders, multiple sclerosis exacerbations, and other conditions as determined by your clinician. How should this medicine be used? It is given by a healthcare professional into a vein or muscle. Dose and duration are individualized based on the condition and response. Do not use by epidural or intrathecal routes. If used for more than a few days, your clinician may taper the dose to prevent adrenal suppression. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have current or recent infection, exposure to chickenpox or measles, diabetes, high blood pressure, glaucoma or cataracts, osteoporosis, stomach ulcers, psychiatric history, seizure disorder, liver or kidney disease, myasthenia gravis, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. Avoid live vaccines while receiving immunosuppressive doses. Some formulations contain benzyl alcohol which should not be used in newborns. Many medicines interact including certain antifungals, antibiotics, seizure medicines, blood thinners, and HIV medicines. What special dietary instructions should I follow? You may be advised to limit sodium, ensure adequate calcium and vitamin D, and manage carbohydrate intake to control blood sugar. Maintain adequate hydration. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you are on a scheduled regimen, take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you are using a taper, contact your clinician for instructions. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include fluid retention, swelling, increased appetite, weight gain, mood changes, anxiety or insomnia, elevated blood pressure, elevated blood sugar, stomach upset, acne, and increased sweating. Serious effects include severe infection, vision changes or eye pain, stomach bleeding, pancreatitis, severe mood or behavior changes, muscle weakness, bone loss, hip or shoulder pain suggestive of avascular necrosis, and adrenal suppression. Injection site reactions can occur.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine. Taking benzodiazepines with opioids can cause profound sedation, severe respiratory depression, coma, and death. Use together only when alternatives are inadequate and with close monitoring. Benzodiazepines can cause misuse, abuse, and addiction, and can lead to physical dependence. Do not stop suddenly after long term use because withdrawal reactions can be severe or life threatening. Why is this medication prescribed? Chlordiazepoxide is used to treat anxiety disorders and symptoms of acute alcohol withdrawal. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth exactly as prescribed, with or without food. Doses for anxiety are usually divided 3 or 4 times daily. Doses for alcohol withdrawal may be higher at first and then tapered. Use the lowest effective dose for the shortest duration. Do not increase the dose or take more often than prescribed. Do not stop suddenly. Your clinician will guide a gradual taper to reduce withdrawal risk. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you use opioids, alcohol, or other sedatives. Avoid alcohol. Tell your clinician if you have liver disease, kidney disease, breathing problems, sleep apnea, depression or other mental health conditions, a history of substance use disorder, glaucoma, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. This medicine may cause drowsiness, dizziness, and impaired coordination; do not drive or operate machinery until you know how it affects you. Many medicines can interact including strong inhibitors or inducers of liver enzymes. Older adults are at higher risk of confusion, falls, and fractures. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid alcohol. If you are sensitive to grapefruit or grapefruit juice, ask your clinician or pharmacist about potential interactions. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it when you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include drowsiness, dizziness, fatigue, confusion, blurred vision, dry mouth, constipation, or coordination problems. Serious effects include severe sedation or breathing problems, agitation, worsening depression, suicidal thoughts, yellowing of the skin or eyes, severe rash, or unusual bleeding. Seek emergency help for trouble breathing or unresponsiveness, especially if taken with opioids or alcohol.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Tetrahydrozoline ophthalmic is used to relieve eye redness due to minor irritation. How should this medicine be used? Wash hands before use. Remove contact lenses. Instill 1 drop in the affected eye every 4 hours as needed. Do not use more than 72 hours in a row to avoid rebound redness. Do not touch the dropper tip to any surface and recap after use. Do not use while wearing contact lenses. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you have narrow angle glaucoma unless directed by a clinician. Stop use and seek care for eye pain, changes in vision, continued redness, or if redness lasts more than 72 hours. Keep out of reach of children because accidental ingestion can cause serious harm such as low heart rate, sleepiness, and low body temperature. Ask your clinician before use during pregnancy or breastfeeding or in young children. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No special dietary instructions are needed. What should I do if I forget a dose? Use as needed. If you are on a schedule, use when you remember unless it is close to the next dose. Do not use extra drops to make up a missed dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Mild transient stinging or burning, temporary blurred vision, or eye irritation may occur. Overuse can cause rebound redness. Seek medical help for severe eye pain, persistent vision changes, severe headache with eye pain, or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Abacavir can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the HLA B*5701 gene variant. You must be tested for HLA B*5701 before starting abacavir. Stop abacavir and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms of hypersensitivity which may include fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms such as cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. Never restart abacavir if you have had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. Why is this medication prescribed? Abacavir is an antiretroviral medicine used with other medicines to treat human immunodeficiency virus infection. How should this medicine be used? Take exactly as prescribed, usually 300 milligrams twice daily or 600 milligrams once daily, with or without food. Take doses at the same times every day. Do not miss doses or stop unless your clinician tells you to. Abacavir should always be used in combination with other antiretrovirals. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have liver disease, risk factors for heart disease, or if you drink alcohol. Abacavir is not recommended in moderate or severe liver disease. Tell your clinician if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. Do not breastfeed if you have HIV. Many medicines can interact; review all medicines and supplements with your clinician. Be aware of possible immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome when starting therapy. What special dietary instructions should I follow? You may take abacavir with or without food. Limit alcohol because it can increase abacavir levels and liver stress. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose. Do not take two doses at once. If you have stopped abacavir for any reason and have symptoms suggestive of hypersensitivity or if the cause of prior symptoms is uncertain, do not restart abacavir and contact your clinician immediately. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include nausea, vomiting, headache, fatigue, and rash. Serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, liver problems such as jaundice or dark urine, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, and chest pain or shortness of breath. Seek medical help right away for signs of hypersensitivity or severe side effects.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: This medicine contains abacavir which can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the HLA B*5701 gene variant. You must be tested for HLA B*5701 before starting. Stop the medicine and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms such as fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms like cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. Never restart if you had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. In people with hepatitis B virus infection, stopping lamivudine can cause a serious flare of hepatitis. Why is this medication prescribed? The fixed dose combination of abacavir, dolutegravir, and lamivudine treats human immunodeficiency virus infection and is used as a complete regimen in appropriate patients. How should this medicine be used? Take one tablet once daily at the same time each day, with or without food. If you take antacids or iron or calcium supplements, take this medicine at least 2 hours before or 6 hours after those products. Do not take with dofetilide. Do not miss doses or stop unless directed by your clinician. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have liver disease or hepatitis B infection, kidney problems, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. Your clinician may check hepatitis B status and liver tests and may prescribe additional hepatitis B treatment if needed. Dolutegravir can interact with many medicines including metformin, multivitamins or supplements containing polyvalent cations, certain anticonvulsants, rifampin, and St Johns wort. This product is not recommended if your creatinine clearance is less than 50 milliliters per minute. Watch for depression or insomnia and report new or worsening mood symptoms. Do not breastfeed if you have HIV. What special dietary instructions should I follow? You may take with or without food. Separate dosing from antacids or iron or calcium supplements as described. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember if it is within about 12 hours of your usual time. If it is close to the time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. Do not take two doses at once. If you vomit within 1 hour after taking a dose, take another dose. Do not restart the medicine after a break if you had any signs of abacavir hypersensitivity without first speaking to your clinician. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, and insomnia. Weight gain can occur. Serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, liver problems including hepatitis flares after stopping in people with hepatitis B, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, depression or suicidal thoughts, and severe skin reactions. Immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome can occur when starting therapy.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: This medicine contains abacavir which can cause a serious and sometimes fatal hypersensitivity reaction that is more likely if you have the HLA B*5701 gene variant. You must be tested for HLA B*5701 before starting. Stop the medicine and seek emergency care if you develop symptoms such as fever, rash, malaise or fatigue, gastrointestinal symptoms like nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain, or respiratory symptoms like cough, sore throat, or shortness of breath. Never restart if you had a suspected hypersensitivity reaction. This medicine also carries a risk of lactic acidosis and severe liver enlargement with fatty liver. Zidovudine can cause bone marrow suppression leading to anemia and neutropenia, and long term use can cause muscle weakness. In people with hepatitis B infection, stopping lamivudine can cause a serious flare of hepatitis. Why is this medication prescribed? The fixed dose combination of abacavir, lamivudine, and zidovudine is used with or without other antiretroviral agents to treat human immunodeficiency virus infection. How should this medicine be used? Take one tablet by mouth twice daily with or without food. Take doses at the same times every day. Do not miss doses or stop unless directed by your clinician. This product may not be suitable if you have significant kidney impairment because lamivudine requires dose adjustment. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have liver disease, hepatitis B or C infection, kidney disease, low blood counts, anemia, or neutropenia, or if you are pregnant or planning pregnancy. Your clinician will check blood counts regularly. Many medicines can interact including ribavirin, doxorubicin, other medicines that affect bone marrow, and alcohol. Do not breastfeed if you have HIV. What special dietary instructions should I follow? You may take with or without food and should limit alcohol to reduce liver stress. Ensure adequate nutrition to support blood counts as advised by your clinician. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is almost time for the next dose, then skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. Do not take two doses at once. If you vomit within 1 hour after a dose, take another dose. Do not restart the medicine after a break if you had any signs of abacavir hypersensitivity without first speaking to your clinician. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include nausea, headache, fatigue, and trouble sleeping. Serious effects include hypersensitivity reaction, anemia, neutropenia, lactic acidosis with severe weakness or unusual muscle pain, liver problems with jaundice or dark urine, pancreatitis, and muscle pain or weakness. Skin or nail discoloration can occur. Seek medical help for shortness of breath, chest pain, severe fatigue, or signs of infection such as fever or persistent sore throat.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: In animal studies abaloparatide caused an increase in bone cancer called osteosarcoma. Because of this potential risk, do not use it if you have conditions that increase your baseline risk for osteosarcoma such as Paget disease of bone, unexplained elevations of alkaline phosphatase, bone metastases or a history of skeletal radiation therapy, or in patients with open epiphyses. Do not use abaloparatide or other parathyroid hormone analogs for more than a total of 2 years during your lifetime. Why is this medication prescribed? Abaloparatide is used to treat osteoporosis in postmenopausal women and in men who are at high risk for fracture, to increase bone density and reduce the risk of fractures. How should this medicine be used? It is given as a subcutaneous injection once daily, usually 80 micrograms, into the abdomen. Use at the same time each day, rotate injection sites, and follow pen preparation instructions. Your clinician will show you how to inject properly. Store and handle the pen exactly as directed on the product label. After completing abaloparatide therapy, your clinician may start an antiresorptive medicine to maintain bone density. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have or had bone cancer, metabolic bone diseases other than osteoporosis, kidney stones, high calcium, severe kidney disease, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. Abaloparatide may cause transient low blood pressure, dizziness, or fast heartbeat after injection, especially at the beginning. Sit or lie down after your dose if you feel lightheaded. Use caution if you take digoxin because high calcium can increase digoxin toxicity. Limit lifetime use of abaloparatide and teriparatide combined to 2 years. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Take calcium and vitamin D as directed to ensure adequate intake. Avoid excessive calcium supplementation if you have a history of kidney stones and maintain good hydration. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a dose, skip it and take your next dose at the usual time the following day. Do not take two doses on the same day. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include dizziness, fast heartbeat, nausea, headache, fatigue, upper abdominal pain, and redness or pain at the injection site. It can raise urine calcium and rarely cause kidney stones. Serious effects include persistent high calcium symptoms such as confusion or severe constipation, allergic reactions like rash, swelling, or trouble breathing, and very rarely a potential risk of osteosarcoma.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Abatacept is used to treat moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, and polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis by modulating the immune response to reduce joint inflammation and damage. How should this medicine be used? It is given by intravenous infusion at weeks 0, 2, and 4, then every 4 weeks, or as a subcutaneous injection once weekly after possible intravenous loading. A healthcare professional will administer infusions. If you self inject, your clinician will teach you proper technique, site rotation, and storage. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have current or recurrent infections, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, tuberculosis exposure, or hepatitis B. You will be screened for latent tuberculosis and hepatitis B before treatment. Do not receive live vaccines during therapy and for a period after stopping. Use caution with other immunosuppressants. Inform your clinician about pregnancy or breastfeeding plans. Seek medical care promptly for fever, cough, shortness of breath, painful urination, or other infection signs. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There are no specific dietary restrictions. If you also take methotrexate or other hepatotoxic drugs, limit alcohol as advised. What should I do if I forget a dose? For subcutaneous dosing, inject as soon as you remember if it is within a few days, then resume your regular schedule. If it is close to the next dose, skip the missed dose and continue as scheduled. Do not double doses. For infusions, contact your clinic to reschedule. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include headache, nausea, runny or stuffy nose, sore throat, and injection site reactions. Serious effects include serious infections such as pneumonia or sepsis, hypersensitivity or infusion reactions, and possible increased risk of certain cancers. Call your clinician for signs of infection or allergic reaction.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: This chimeric antigen receptor T cell therapy can cause life threatening cytokine release syndrome and neurologic toxicities. It can also cause hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis or macrophage activation syndrome and prolonged or recurrent low blood counts. It must be given at a certified center with tocilizumab and intensive care support immediately available. Seek emergency care for fever, chills, confusion, severe headache, seizure, difficulty speaking, severe weakness, shortness of breath, chest pain, or low blood pressure. Why is this medication prescribed? Idecabtagene vicleucel is used to treat adults with relapsed or refractory multiple myeloma who have received prior therapies and meet specific criteria. How should this medicine be used? It is given once as an intravenous infusion after a short course of lymphodepleting chemotherapy. You will be monitored closely in the hospital or clinic and must remain near the treating center for at least 4 weeks. Do not drive or operate heavy machinery for at least 8 weeks after infusion due to the risk of neurologic events. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about all infections, vaccination history, and if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. You will be screened for hepatitis and other infections. Avoid live vaccines for at least 6 weeks before lymphodepletion and until your clinician says it is safe afterward. Idecabtagene vicleucel can cause prolonged low blood counts, serious infections, low immunoglobulins, and secondary cancers, so you will need frequent blood tests and may receive antimicrobials or immunoglobulin replacement. Some patients may have a false positive test for HIV due to the lentiviral vector. Do not donate blood, organs, tissues, or cells. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There are no specific food restrictions. If your white blood cells are low, follow food safety guidance to reduce infection risk and stay well hydrated. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is administered by professionals. If you miss a scheduled visit or premedication, contact your treatment center immediately for instructions. What side effects can this medication cause? Very common effects include fever, chills, low blood pressure, rapid heart rate, low oxygen levels, fatigue, headache, confusion, tremor, speech difficulty, or sleepiness. Laboratory abnormalities include low white cells, red cells, and platelets, elevated liver enzymes, and electrolyte changes. Serious risks include cytokine release syndrome, severe neurologic events including seizures and encephalopathy, hemophagocytic lymphohistiocytosis, severe infections, tumor lysis syndrome, and prolonged cytopenias.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Different formulations of amphotericin B are not interchangeable and the dosing is not the same. Verify the product name and dose carefully to avoid fatal overdoses. Use only for treatment of invasive or potentially life threatening fungal infections. Why is this medication prescribed? Amphotericin B lipid complex treats severe invasive fungal infections such as aspergillosis, candidiasis, and other susceptible mycoses, especially in patients who cannot tolerate or did not respond to conventional amphotericin B. How should this medicine be used? It is given by intravenous infusion, usually once daily, prepared and diluted exactly as directed, typically in dextrose 5 percent solution, and infused over about 2 hours. It must not be interchanged dose for dose with other amphotericin products. Premedication may reduce infusion reactions. Kidney function, electrolytes, liver tests, and blood counts will be monitored regularly. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about kidney disease, electrolyte problems, liver disease, anemia, pregnancy, or prior reactions to amphotericin. Avoid or minimize other nephrotoxic drugs such as certain NSAIDs, aminoglycosides, and contrast dye. Infusion reactions such as fever, chills, chest or back pain, shortness of breath, and low blood pressure can occur and require monitoring. Severe allergic reactions can occur. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Maintain good hydration as advised. You may need potassium and magnesium supplementation if your levels fall. Limit alcohol and avoid over the counter nephrotoxic medicines unless approved. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is given by healthcare professionals. If a dose or appointment is missed, contact your clinician to reschedule as soon as possible. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, headache, infusion site reactions, and low potassium or magnesium. Kidney function may worsen. Anemia and abnormal liver tests can occur. Serious reactions include severe infusion reactions, anaphylaxis, severe kidney injury, breathing problems, and low blood pressure.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Abemaciclib is a cyclin dependent kinase 4 and 6 inhibitor used for hormone receptor positive, human epidermal growth factor receptor 2 negative breast cancer in metastatic or advanced disease and in some high risk early breast cancer settings, alone or with endocrine therapy. How should this medicine be used? Take the tablets by mouth twice daily at about the same times each day with or without food. Swallow tablets whole. If you vomit after a dose, do not retake the dose and take the next dose at the scheduled time. Your dose may be adjusted based on side effects. Start antidiarrheal medicine at the first sign of loose stools and increase fluids. Your clinician will monitor blood counts and liver tests regularly. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about liver disease, clotting history, lung disease, infections, and all medicines and supplements. Abemaciclib can cause diarrhea, neutropenia, liver injury, blood clots, and interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis. Seek care for shortness of breath, chest pain, or severe diarrhea. Avoid strong CYP3A inhibitors or inducers including certain antifungals, anticonvulsants, and St Johns wort, or follow dose adjustments. Use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose. Do not breastfeed during treatment and for a period after the last dose. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid grapefruit and Seville oranges as they can increase drug levels. Maintain good hydration, especially if you have diarrhea. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a dose, skip it and take your next dose at the usual time. Do not take extra tablets to make up a missed dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include diarrhea, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, abdominal pain, infections, low white blood cells, anemia, low platelets, and elevated liver enzymes. Serious effects include dehydration, blood clots, liver injury, and interstitial lung disease or pneumonitis.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Elderly patients with dementia related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs are at increased risk of death. Aripiprazole is not approved for dementia related psychosis. Antidepressants, including aripiprazole when used as an adjunct for depression, increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults. Monitor closely for worsening depression or suicidality. Why is this medication prescribed? Aripiprazole is used to treat schizophrenia, bipolar I disorder, irritability associated with autistic disorder, Tourette disorder, and as an adjunctive treatment for major depressive disorder. How should this medicine be used? Take aripiprazole by mouth once daily with or without food, at the same time each day. Follow your clinician’s dosing instructions. Do not stop suddenly without medical advice. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about heart disease, stroke risk, diabetes or risk factors, seizures, low white blood cell counts, liver problems, pregnancy, and breastfeeding. Aripiprazole can cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar and diabetes, weight gain and lipid changes, orthostatic hypotension, low white cells, seizures, impulse control problems such as compulsive gambling, temperature regulation problems, and difficulty swallowing. Avoid alcohol and use caution driving until you know how it affects you. Interactions with CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 inhibitors or inducers may require dose changes. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There are no specific food restrictions, but limit alcohol. Maintain healthy nutrition and exercise to reduce metabolic side effects. Discuss grapefruit products with your clinician if you consume them regularly. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. If it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include akathisia or restlessness, anxiety, insomnia or sleepiness, headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting, constipation, and blurred vision. Serious effects include neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar or ketoacidosis, stroke in elderly patients with dementia, seizures, low blood pressure or fainting, and allergic reactions.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Elderly patients with dementia related psychosis treated with antipsychotic drugs are at increased risk of death. Aripiprazole is not approved for dementia related psychosis. Antidepressants, including aripiprazole when used as an adjunct for depression, increase the risk of suicidal thoughts and behaviors in children, adolescents, and young adults. Monitor closely for worsening mood or suicidality. Why is this medication prescribed? Intramuscular aripiprazole is used for acute agitation associated with schizophrenia or bipolar I disorder, and long acting formulations are used for maintenance treatment of schizophrenia and for maintenance monotherapy or adjunct in bipolar I disorder. How should this medicine be used? Short acting aripiprazole is given as intramuscular injections by a healthcare professional. Long acting injections are given into the gluteal or deltoid muscle at intervals such as monthly or every 6 to 8 weeks depending on the product, with a specific initiation plan and in some cases oral overlap. Do not inject intravenously and do not self inject unless specifically trained for a particular product. Attend all scheduled injection appointments. What special precautions should I follow? The same precautions as oral aripiprazole apply including risk of neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, metabolic changes, orthostatic hypotension, leukopenia, seizures, and impulse control disorders. Tell your clinician about all medicines including CYP2D6 and CYP3A4 inhibitors or inducers which may require dose adjustments. Use caution with other central nervous system depressants. Avoid alcohol. Pregnancy in the third trimester can cause symptoms in the newborn. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There are no specific food restrictions. Maintain healthy diet and limit alcohol. What should I do if I forget a dose? Contact your clinician as soon as possible to arrange a catch up injection. The timing of the next dose depends on how long it has been since your last injection and the product used. Do not try to self inject to make up a missed dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include injection site pain, akathisia, restlessness, sleepiness, dizziness, headache, nausea, constipation, and anxiety. Serious effects include neuroleptic malignant syndrome, tardive dyskinesia, high blood sugar, stroke in elderly patients with dementia, orthostatic hypotension or fainting, seizures, and allergic reactions.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Abiraterone is used with prednisone and androgen deprivation therapy to treat metastatic castration resistant prostate cancer and metastatic high risk castration sensitive prostate cancer. It lowers androgen production that fuels prostate cancer. How should this medicine be used? Take abiraterone tablets by mouth once daily on an empty stomach, at least 1 hour before or 2 hours after food, and swallow whole. Take prednisone exactly as prescribed to reduce side effects and continue androgen deprivation therapy unless you have had surgical castration. Your clinician will monitor liver tests, potassium, blood pressure, and fluid status regularly. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about liver disease, heart disease, hypertension, low potassium, adrenal problems, and all medicines and supplements. Abiraterone can cause mineralocorticoid excess leading to high blood pressure, low potassium, and fluid retention, adrenal insufficiency especially if prednisone is interrupted or during stress or infection, and liver injury. Seek care for dark urine, yellow skin or eyes, severe fatigue, shortness of breath, or severe swelling. Avoid strong CYP3A4 inducers or inhibitors if possible. Women who are pregnant or may become pregnant should not handle crushed or broken tablets. Do not use during pregnancy and do not breastfeed. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Always take abiraterone on an empty stomach. Taking it with food can greatly increase drug levels and toxicity. Limit alcohol to protect the liver and avoid grapefruit products and St Johns wort. Ensure adequate potassium intake as advised. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a dose, take your next dose at the regular time the following day. Do not take extra tablets to make up the missed dose. If you miss prednisone doses, contact your clinician for instructions. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include fatigue, joint swelling or pain, hot flushes, diarrhea, cough, shortness of breath, edema, high blood pressure, low potassium, and abnormal liver tests. Serious effects include liver injury, adrenal insufficiency, heart rhythm problems, and severe fluid retention.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Methotrexate can cause severe and sometimes fatal toxicities including bone marrow suppression leading to serious infections and bleeding, liver damage including fibrosis and cirrhosis, kidney damage especially with high doses, lung injury including pneumonitis, severe skin reactions, gastrointestinal ulceration and bleeding, and embryo fetal toxicity. For noncancer indications such as rheumatoid arthritis or psoriasis it must be taken once weekly, not daily. Fatal accidents have occurred when daily dosing was used by mistake. Use only under close medical supervision with regular blood tests. Avoid use during pregnancy and breastfeeding. Why is this medication prescribed? Methotrexate is used to treat certain cancers such as leukemia, lymphomas, and osteosarcoma, and severe psoriasis and rheumatoid arthritis that have not responded to other treatments. How should this medicine be used? It may be given by subcutaneous, intramuscular, intravenous, intraarterial, or intrathecal routes depending on the regimen. For arthritis and psoriasis it is usually given once weekly. Your clinician will determine the route, dose, and schedule. If you self inject subcutaneously, you will be trained on injection technique and site rotation. High dose regimens require leucovorin rescue, aggressive hydration, and urinary alkalinization with close monitoring of drug levels and kidney function. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about liver or kidney disease, lung disease, peptic ulcer disease, fluid collections such as pleural effusions or ascites, low blood counts, infections, and all medicines and supplements. Many drugs increase methotrexate toxicity including trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole, penicillins, proton pump inhibitors, and certain NSAIDs especially with high doses. Avoid live vaccines. Use effective contraception during treatment and for a period after the last dose. Seek urgent care for cough or shortness of breath, mouth ulcers, severe rash, fever, bruising or bleeding, dark urine or yellowing of the skin or eyes, or severe abdominal pain. Folic acid supplementation is commonly prescribed to reduce some side effects. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid alcohol to reduce the risk of liver toxicity. Stay well hydrated. Take folic acid as directed. Limit excessive caffeine if advised by your clinician. What should I do if I forget a dose? For weekly regimens, if you remember within 2 days of the scheduled dose, take it as soon as possible and then resume your normal weekly schedule. If more than 2 days have passed, call your clinician for instructions. For cancer regimens or intrathecal dosing, contact your treatment team immediately for guidance. Do not double doses. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include nausea, vomiting, decreased appetite, stomach pain, mouth sores, diarrhea, headache, dizziness, and fatigue. Laboratory changes include elevated liver enzymes and low blood counts. Serious effects include severe bone marrow suppression with infections and bleeding, liver fibrosis or cirrhosis with long term use, kidney failure especially with high doses, lung inflammation or scarring, severe skin reactions such as Stevens Johnson syndrome or toxic epidermal necrolysis, gastrointestinal perforation or bleeding, and neurologic toxicity with intrathecal use.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: The effects of botulinum toxin may spread from the area of injection to produce symptoms consistent with botulism. These may include asthenia, generalized muscle weakness, double or blurred vision, drooping eyelids, trouble speaking or swallowing, and trouble breathing. These symptoms can occur hours to weeks after injection and can be life threatening. Children treated for spasticity are at greatest risk. Seek emergency care for swallowing or breathing difficulties. Why is this medication prescribed? AbobotulinumtoxinA is used to treat cervical dystonia, upper limb spasticity in adults, lower limb spasticity in pediatric patients 2 years and older, and to temporarily improve the appearance of moderate to severe glabellar lines. How should this medicine be used? It is injected into muscles by a trained clinician. Units are specific to this product and are not interchangeable with other botulinum toxin products. Dosing and injection sites are individualized. Effects usually begin within a few days and peak around 2 weeks, and repeat treatments are typically given every 12 to 16 weeks as needed. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about neuromuscular disorders, breathing or swallowing problems, bleeding disorders, planned surgery, and all medicines including aminoglycoside antibiotics and muscle relaxants that can increase weakness. Hypersensitivity reactions can occur. Use caution if you have a history of dysphagia or respiratory compromise. Do not receive another botulinum toxin within the recommended interval unless directed. What special dietary instructions should I follow? There are no specific dietary restrictions. If you develop difficulty swallowing, follow your clinicians guidance, which may include soft foods or thickened liquids to reduce aspiration risk. What should I do if I forget a dose? This medicine is given by a healthcare professional. If you miss an appointment, contact your clinician to reschedule. Do not attempt self injection. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include injection site pain, localized muscle weakness, dry mouth, fatigue, headache, and upper respiratory symptoms. In cervical dystonia, difficulty swallowing is common. Serious effects include breathing difficulties, aspiration pneumonia, severe allergic reactions, and generalized muscle weakness from toxin spread.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: This medicine can cause severe decreases in blood cell counts that raise the risk of serious or fatal infection and bleeding. It can harm an unborn baby. It must be given only under the supervision of clinicians experienced with cancer chemotherapy, with frequent blood count checks and dose changes as needed. Why is this medication prescribed? Paclitaxel with albumin is used to treat certain cancers including breast cancer, non small cell lung cancer, and pancreatic cancer. How should this medicine be used? It is given as an intravenous infusion by a trained professional on a repeating cycle schedule. Premedication for allergic reactions is usually not required with the albumin bound form, but you will be monitored closely during and after infusions. Your care team will adjust dose timing based on your blood counts, side effects, liver tests, and treatment response. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor about all health conditions including infections, liver problems, heart problems, numbness or tingling, and pregnancy or plans to become pregnant. Use effective birth control during treatment and for at least several months after the last dose as directed by your oncologist. Do not breastfeed during treatment. Tell your doctor about all medicines and supplements. Some drugs that affect liver enzymes such as CYP3A4 or CYP2C8 and herbal products like St Johns wort can change paclitaxel levels. Report fever, chills, sore throat, unusual bruising or bleeding, shortness of breath, severe diarrhea, or signs of allergic reaction right away. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice unless your oncology team says otherwise. Stay well hydrated unless you have been told to restrict fluids. What should I do if I forget a dose? Call your clinic as soon as possible to reschedule. Do not try to self administer this medicine. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include low white blood cells, anemia, low platelets, hair loss, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, mouth sores, muscle or joint aches, and numbness or tingling in the hands or feet. Serious effects can include severe infection, sepsis, severe allergic reactions, liver test changes, severe neuropathy, and rare heart or lung problems. Seek urgent care for fever, breathing trouble, chest pain, severe weakness, or severe rash.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Medicines that block tumor necrosis factor including adalimumab increase the risk of serious and sometimes fatal infections such as tuberculosis and invasive fungal infections and may raise the risk of certain cancers including lymphoma. You must be screened for tuberculosis and monitored for infection during and after treatment. Why is this medication prescribed? Adalimumab is used to reduce inflammation in conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, ankylosing spondylitis, plaque psoriasis, Crohns disease, ulcerative colitis, hidradenitis suppurativa, uveitis, and some forms of juvenile arthritis. How should this medicine be used? It is injected under the skin using a prefilled pen or syringe on a regular schedule, usually every one to two weeks depending on the condition. Store in the refrigerator and allow it to reach room temperature before use. Do not shake. Inject into the thigh or abdomen and rotate sites. Your clinician will show you how to prepare, inject, and dispose of supplies safely. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor about all infections or symptoms such as fever, cough, weight loss, night sweats, or sores. Tell your doctor if you have or had hepatitis B, tuberculosis, cancer, demyelinating disease such as multiple sclerosis, heart failure, or immune system problems. Complete recommended vaccines before starting and avoid live vaccines during treatment. Some needle covers contain latex, so mention any latex allergy. Tell your clinician about all medicines, especially other biologic drugs, immunosuppressants, and blood thinners. If you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and timing of doses. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific diet is required. Maintain good hydration and nutrition. What should I do if I forget a dose? Inject the missed dose as soon as you remember, then return to your regular schedule. If it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. Do not inject two doses at the same time. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include injection site pain or redness, upper respiratory symptoms, headache, rash, and nausea. Serious effects include severe infections, tuberculosis reactivation, hepatitis B reactivation, certain cancers, low blood counts, new or worsening heart failure, nerve problems, lupus like symptoms, and severe allergic reactions. Seek urgent care for signs of infection, trouble breathing, severe weakness, chest pain, or severe rash.

name: Phenylephrine
text: Important warning: Abrocitinib increases the risk of serious infections, death, cancer, major adverse cardiovascular events such as heart attack and stroke, and blood clots. Use only in patients who have not responded to or cannot tolerate other therapies and after discussing risks and benefits. Why is this medication prescribed? Abrocitinib is an oral Janus kinase inhibitor used to treat moderate to severe atopic dermatitis in adults and certain adolescents when topical therapies are not adequate. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth once daily as directed, with or without food, swallowing tablets whole with water. Your doctor may adjust the dose based on age, kidney or liver function, platelet counts, and side effects. Do not crush or split the tablets. What special precautions should I follow? Before starting, your doctor will check for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and current infections, and will order blood tests including a complete blood count, liver tests, and cholesterol. Avoid live vaccines during treatment. Tell your doctor about any history of heart disease, stroke, blood clots, cancer, smoking, diabetes, stomach or bowel problems, or kidney or liver disease. Use effective birth control while taking abrocitinib and for a time after the last dose as directed by your prescriber. Do not breastfeed during treatment and for some time after the last dose. Tell your doctor about all medicines and supplements. Strong inhibitors or inducers of certain liver enzymes especially those that affect CYP2C19 or CYP2C9 can change abrocitinib levels. Report signs of infection, chest pain, trouble breathing, severe stomach pain, leg swelling, severe headache, vision changes, shingles, or unusual bruising or bleeding right away. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific foods are required. Take with food if nausea occurs. Avoid herbal products with strong enzyme effects such as St Johns wort unless your clinician approves. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a dose and remember on the same day, take it as soon as you remember. If you do not remember until the next day, skip the missed dose and resume your usual schedule. Do not take two doses in one day. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include nausea, headache, dizziness, acne, stomach pain, and upper respiratory symptoms. Lab changes can include increases in cholesterol and decreases in platelets. Serious effects include serious infections such as shingles, blood clots, heart attack, stroke, cancer, gastrointestinal perforation, liver test elevations, and severe allergic reactions.

name: RSV (Respiratory Syncytial Virus) Vaccine
text: Why is this medication prescribed? RSV vaccines help prevent lower respiratory tract disease caused by respiratory syncytial virus in adults 60 years and older based on shared clinical decision making, and one vaccine is approved for use during pregnancy to protect infants. How should this medicine be used? It is given as a single intramuscular injection by a healthcare professional. For pregnant people, the vaccine is given during weeks 32 to 36 of pregnancy, typically during RSV season, as advised by the obstetric provider. For older adults, timing is usually before or during RSV season based on risk factors and local guidance. What special precautions should I follow? Do not receive the vaccine if you had a severe allergic reaction to a previous dose or any component of the vaccine. Tell your provider if you have a history of Guillain Barre syndrome, are ill with fever, are pregnant or breastfeeding, or have immune system conditions. Discuss the timing of this vaccine with other vaccines. Remain at the clinic for observation after vaccination. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No dietary changes are needed. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a planned appointment, reschedule with your clinic. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include pain, redness, or swelling at the injection site, tiredness, headache, muscle or joint aches, and fever or chills. Serious reactions such as severe allergic reaction are rare and require immediate medical attention. Rare cases of Guillain Barre syndrome have been reported in some older adults.

name: Lidocaine Transdermal Patch
text: Why is this medication prescribed? The lidocaine skin patch is used to relieve nerve related pain in the area of a shingles rash after it has healed and may be used for certain localized pain conditions as directed by a clinician. How should this medicine be used? Apply the patch to intact, dry skin over the painful area, usually once daily for up to 12 hours in a 24 hour period. Do not use more than three patches at one time unless your clinician instructs you to do so. You may cut patches to fit. Wash hands after handling and avoid touching eyes or mouth. Do not apply external heat such as heating pads over the patch. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you have had an allergic reaction to lidocaine or other amide local anesthetics. Use caution if you have severe liver disease, heart rhythm problems, or a history of methemoglobinemia. Do not apply to broken or inflamed skin. Keep out of reach of children and pets and fold and dispose of used patches safely. Tell your doctor about all medicines, especially other local anesthetics, heart rhythm medicines, beta blockers, and medicines that can cause methemoglobinemia. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No dietary changes are needed. What should I do if I forget a dose? Apply a patch when you remember and remove it at your usual time so that total wear time does not exceed 12 hours in any 24 hour period. Do not apply extra patches to make up for a missed dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include skin redness, irritation, or a mild burning sensation where applied. Rare but serious effects from too much lidocaine in the body include dizziness, drowsiness, confusion, blurred vision, ringing in the ears, seizures, slow or irregular heartbeat, or breathing problems. Remove the patch and seek urgent care if serious symptoms occur.

name: Isotretinoin
text: Important warning: Isotretinoin causes severe birth defects. Do not use if you are pregnant or may become pregnant. Enrollment in the iPLEDGE program is required in the United States with strict pregnancy testing and contraception requirements. Do not donate blood during treatment or for a period after the last dose. Why is this medication prescribed? Isotretinoin is used to treat severe nodular acne that has not responded to other treatments. How should this medicine be used? Take capsules by mouth as directed, usually twice daily. Take with food to improve absorption unless you are prescribed a formulation that can be taken without regard to meals. Swallow capsules whole. Your doctor will monitor blood tests including lipids and liver tests and adjust the dose based on response and side effects. What special precautions should I follow? Do not become pregnant during treatment or for at least one month after the last dose. Use two effective methods of birth control as directed by your prescriber. Do not breastfeed during treatment. Tell your doctor about any history of depression, mood disorders, high triglycerides, liver disease, diabetes, bone disorders, or bowel disease. Tell your doctor about all medicines and supplements. Avoid vitamin A supplements, tetracycline antibiotics, and St Johns wort, and discuss use of progestin only contraceptives. Report mood changes, severe headache, vision changes, chest pain, severe stomach pain, blood in stool, severe muscle or joint pain, or signs of pancreatitis or liver problems right away. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Take with meals and avoid alcohol or limit it as advised to reduce liver and triglyceride risks. Avoid vitamin A rich supplements. Stay well hydrated and use lip and skin moisturizers. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take the missed dose when you remember unless it is close to the time for the next dose. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Very common effects include dry or chapped lips, dry skin and eyes, nosebleeds, and increased sun sensitivity. Other effects may include headache, back or joint pain, changes in vision or hearing, elevated triglycerides and liver enzymes, rash, and fatigue. Serious effects include birth defects if used during pregnancy, mood or behavior changes, pancreatitis, severe liver problems, inflammatory bowel symptoms, pseudotumor cerebri, and severe skin reactions. Seek urgent care for severe headache with vision changes, chest pain, shortness of breath, severe abdominal pain, or signs of allergic reaction.

name: Fentanyl
text: Important warning: Fentanyl is a potent opioid that can cause life threatening addiction, abuse, and misuse, and can cause fatal breathing problems especially when starting or increasing the dose. Accidental exposure, especially in children, can be deadly. Combining fentanyl with benzodiazepines, alcohol, or other sedatives can cause profound sedation, breathing problems, coma, and death. Use exactly as prescribed and store securely. Why is this medication prescribed? Fentanyl is used to treat severe pain that requires continuous opioid therapy or breakthrough cancer pain in patients who are already taking and tolerant to opioid medicines. How should this medicine be used? The form and directions depend on the product. Skin patches deliver medicine over 72 hours and are for patients already taking opioids. Apply to clean intact skin, press firmly, and replace every 72 hours rotating sites. Do not use heat sources on or near the patch. Buccal, sublingual, or nasal products are used for breakthrough cancer pain and are taken as single doses with careful titration. Injectable forms are given by trained professionals. Do not cut or alter patches or take more than prescribed. Your clinician will provide a plan for starting dose, titration, and safe disposal. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about lung disease, sleep apnea, head injury, seizures, liver or kidney disease, low blood pressure, mental health conditions, constipation, or past substance use disorder. Tell your clinician about all medicines and supplements. Avoid combining with other sedatives unless directed. Strong CYP3A4 inhibitors or inducers and many other drugs can dangerously change fentanyl levels. Risk of serotonin syndrome increases with serotonergic drugs. Do not use patches if you are not already taking opioid medicines on a regular schedule. Keep naloxone available and ensure household members know how to use it. Avoid driving or operating machinery until you know how fentanyl affects you. If pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks which include neonatal withdrawal. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Do not drink alcohol. Avoid grapefruit and grapefruit juice which can raise fentanyl levels. Stay hydrated and increase fiber in your diet to help prevent constipation. What should I do if I forget a dose? For a skin patch, apply a new patch as soon as you remember and remove the old one, then continue on the new 72 hour schedule. If a patch falls off, dispose of it safely and apply a new patch to a different site. For buccal, sublingual, or nasal products, if a dose is missed, use it when pain recurs unless it is close to the time you would normally use the next dose. Never use extra doses to make up for a missed dose. When unsure, contact your prescriber. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include constipation, nausea, vomiting, sleepiness, dizziness, confusion, sweating, and itching. Serious effects include slow or shallow breathing, severe sleepiness, fainting, severe low blood pressure, serotonin syndrome, adrenal insufficiency, allergic reactions, and in long term use low sex hormones. Seek emergency help for breathing problems, severe drowsiness, inability to wake, or signs of overdose.

name: Acalabrutinib
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Acalabrutinib is used to treat certain blood cancers including chronic lymphocytic leukemia, small lymphocytic lymphoma, and mantle cell lymphoma in some situations. How should this medicine be used? Take acalabrutinib by mouth as directed, typically twice daily. Swallow capsules or tablets whole with water. If you take acid reducing medicines, avoid proton pump inhibitors. If you use H2 blockers, take acalabrutinib at least two hours after the H2 blocker. If you use antacids, separate doses by at least two hours. Your doctor may adjust dosing with certain interacting medicines. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor about any history of bleeding, heart rhythm problems including atrial fibrillation, high blood pressure, infections, liver disease, or kidney disease. This medicine can increase bleeding and infection risk and can cause low blood counts and heart rhythm problems. Tell your doctor about all medicines and supplements. Strong CYP3A inhibitors or inducers and grapefruit or Seville oranges can change acalabrutinib levels. Your doctor may recommend infection prevention steps. Use sun protection because of a risk of second primary skin cancers. Tell your dentist or surgeon that you take acalabrutinib before procedures. If you are pregnant, plan to become pregnant, or breastfeeding, discuss risks and effective contraception during and after treatment. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Avoid grapefruit, grapefruit juice, and Seville oranges. Otherwise, no specific diet is required. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you miss a dose by less than three hours, take it as soon as you remember. If more than three hours have passed, skip the missed dose and take the next dose at the regular time. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include headache, diarrhea, muscle or joint pain, fatigue, bruising, and rash. Laboratory changes may include low white blood cells, low platelets, and anemia. Serious effects include severe infections, significant bleeding, atrial fibrillation, high blood pressure, and second primary cancers. Seek prompt care for chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, black stools, severe bleeding, or signs of infection such as fever or chills.

name: Acamprosate
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Acamprosate helps people with alcohol use disorder maintain abstinence as part of a comprehensive treatment program that includes counseling and support. How should this medicine be used? Take acamprosate by mouth exactly as prescribed, usually three times daily. Swallow delayed release tablets whole with water. It is typically started after you have stopped drinking. Dose adjustments are needed in reduced kidney function and it is not recommended in severe kidney disease. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your doctor about kidney problems, depression, suicidal thoughts, or other mental health conditions. Report any mood or behavior changes or suicidal thoughts right away. Tell your doctor about all medicines and supplements. Continue counseling and support programs. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. What special dietary instructions should I follow? You may take it with or without food. If stomach upset occurs, taking it with meals may help. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take the missed dose as soon as you remember unless it is close to the time for your next dose. If it is almost time for the next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include diarrhea, nausea, gas, itching, dizziness, insomnia, anxiety, and weakness. Serious effects are rare but can include depression, suicidal thoughts, allergic reactions, and severe diarrhea. Seek help if you develop severe mood changes or signs of an allergic reaction.

name: Benzoyl Peroxide Topical
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Benzoyl peroxide is used on the skin to treat acne by reducing acne causing bacteria and helping keep pores clear. How should this medicine be used? Use as directed on the label or by your clinician. Clean and dry the affected skin, then apply a thin layer once daily and increase to twice daily as tolerated. Avoid eyes, lips, inside the nose, and broken skin. Wash hands after application. It can bleach hair and fabrics. If you use other acne medicines, apply at different times of day to reduce irritation. What special precautions should I follow? Do a small test area at first to check for irritation. Stop and seek care if you develop severe redness, swelling, blistering, or difficulty breathing. Tell your clinician if you have very sensitive skin or eczema. Avoid excessive sun and use sunscreen since irritation can increase sun sensitivity. Do not use at the same time as dapsone on the same area because temporary skin discoloration can occur. If pregnant or breastfeeding, it is generally considered acceptable, but discuss with your clinician. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No dietary changes are needed. What should I do if I forget a dose? Apply when you remember, but if it is close to the next application, skip the missed dose and resume your normal schedule. Do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include dryness, peeling, mild burning or stinging, and redness. Less common but serious reactions include severe swelling, blistering, hives, or allergic reactions. If severe irritation occurs, stop use and contact your clinician.

name: Clindamycin and Benzoyl Peroxide Topical
text: Why is this medication prescribed? This combination is used on the skin to treat acne. Clindamycin reduces acne causing bacteria and inflammation, and benzoyl peroxide helps reduce bacteria and unclog pores. How should this medicine be used? Use on the skin only. Clean and dry the affected area, then apply a thin layer as directed, usually once or twice daily. Avoid contact with eyes, inside the nose or mouth, and broken or irritated skin. Wash hands after applying. Use a gentle cleanser and a noncomedogenic moisturizer. This medicine can bleach hair and fabrics and can increase sun sensitivity, so use sunscreen and protective clothing. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician about any history of colitis, inflammatory bowel disease, or antibiotic associated diarrhea. Do not use if you are allergic to clindamycin, lincomycin, or benzoyl peroxide. Avoid using other topical acne products that can irritate the skin unless your clinician advises it. Stop and contact your clinician if you develop severe diarrhea, abdominal cramps, severe skin irritation, or signs of allergy such as hives or swelling. If you are pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss the risks and benefits. What special dietary instructions should I follow? No specific diet is needed. Use adequate sun protection. What should I do if I forget a dose? Apply it as soon as you remember, but if it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not apply extra to make up for a missed dose. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include dryness, peeling, redness, burning, stinging, and itching. It may increase sun sensitivity. Less common but serious effects include severe skin irritation or allergic reaction and rarely severe or persistent diarrhea due to colitis. Seek medical help for severe worsening or signs of allergy.

name: Acarbose
text: Why is this medication prescribed? Acarbose is used with diet and exercise to improve blood sugar control in adults with type 2 diabetes. It slows the digestion of carbohydrates to reduce post meal blood sugar spikes. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth at the first bite of each main meal, usually three times daily. Your clinician may start with a low dose and increase gradually to improve tolerance. Monitor blood sugar as directed and have periodic blood tests including liver enzymes. Do not use it to treat low blood sugar. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you have inflammatory bowel disease, colonic ulceration, partial intestinal obstruction, chronic intestinal disorders with marked digestion or absorption issues, or cirrhosis. Tell your clinician if you have kidney or liver disease, are pregnant or breastfeeding, or use other diabetes medicines. Treat low blood sugar with pure glucose such as dextrose tablets or gel, not table sugar or sucrose containing foods, because acarbose delays the breakdown of sucrose. Activated charcoal and digestive enzyme products can reduce the effect of acarbose. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Follow your diabetes meal plan and distribute carbohydrate intake evenly. Limit alcohol and avoid using table sugar to treat low blood sugar. High fiber foods may increase gas at the start of therapy. What should I do if I forget a dose? If you skip a meal, skip the acarbose dose. If you forget to take it with a meal, do not take it later between meals. Take the next dose at the first bite of your next main meal. Do not double doses. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects are gas, abdominal discomfort, bloating, and diarrhea, which often lessen over time. It can cause low blood sugar when used with insulin or other diabetes drugs. Less common effects include elevated liver enzymes or liver inflammation, rash, or swelling. Seek care for yellowing of the skin or eyes, dark urine, severe abdominal pain, or persistent vomiting.

name: Zafirlukast
text: Important warning: Zafirlukast can cause serious liver injury. Stop the medicine and contact your clinician right away if you develop fatigue, loss of appetite, nausea, abdominal pain, itching, dark urine, or yellowing of the skin or eyes. This medicine does not treat sudden asthma attacks. Always keep a rescue inhaler available. Why is this medication prescribed? Zafirlukast is used to prevent and control asthma symptoms by blocking leukotrienes, substances that cause airway inflammation. How should this medicine be used? Take by mouth on an empty stomach, either one hour before or two hours after meals, usually twice daily. Take it regularly even if you feel well. Do not use it to relieve acute wheezing. If you are tapering oral steroids, this must be done under medical supervision. What special precautions should I follow? Do not use if you have liver disease or cirrhosis. Tell your clinician about all medicines, especially warfarin, theophylline, and erythromycin, because interactions may occur. Report any signs of liver problems. Rarely, worsening asthma with eosinophilia and vasculitis can occur, especially when oral steroids are reduced. If pregnant or breastfeeding, discuss risks and benefits. What special dietary instructions should I follow? Take on an empty stomach for best absorption. Avoid excessive alcohol due to liver risk. What should I do if I forget a dose? Take it as soon as you remember unless it is close to the next dose. If it is almost time for your next dose, skip the missed dose. Do not take two doses at once. What side effects can this medication cause? Common effects include headache, nausea, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and infections. Serious effects include liver enzyme elevations, hepatitis, jaundice, allergic reactions, and rare vasculitis with rash, tingling or numbness, and worsening lung symptoms.

name: Somatropin Injection
text: Important warning: Do not use somatropin in patients with severe obesity or severe breathing problems who have Prader Willi syndrome due to risk of sudden death. Do not use somatropin in patients with acute critical illness after major surgery, trauma, or with acute respiratory failure. Why is this medication prescribed? Somatropin is a form of human growth hormone used to treat growth failure in children and growth hormone deficiency in adults, and certain conditions such as Turner syndrome, chronic kidney disease before transplant, small for gestational age with failure to catch up growth, and other approved indications. How should this medicine be used? It is given as a subcutaneous injection once daily or as directed. Your dose is individualized and may be adjusted based on weight and insulin like growth factor one levels. You will be taught how to prepare and inject the medicine, rotate injection sites, and store it in the refrigerator. Do not shake the product. Use only the device and needles provided and do not share injection devices. What special precautions should I follow? Tell your clinician if you have any cancer, a history of a brain tumor, diabetic retinopathy, active proliferative or severe nonproliferative retinopathy, or if you are pregnant or breastfeeding. Do not use if you have active malignancy. Use caution if you have diabetes or glucose intolerance, adrenal or thyroid disorders, scoliosis, obstructive sleep apnea, hip problems, pancreatitis, or a history of intracranial hypertension. Report severe headache with visual changes, hip or knee pain with limping, abdominal pain, swelling of hands or feet, numbness or tingling in the hands, or signs of cancer recurrence.
